Award.AwardTitle: Laser Processing Method to Reduce Solar Cell Manufacturing Cost and Enhancement of Performance

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Silicon based solar cells continue to dominate the solar-energy market, accounting for over 85 percent of all solar cell products in the world. The decrease in manufacturing cost of silicon solar cells is extremely important in order for solar-energy technology to be a viable alternative energy source. High-power lasers provide an attractive method to lower the cost of solar cell manufacturing. However, further research is required in order to make high-power laser-based processing viable for solar cell manufacturing and to be adapted by industry. This research focuses on scientific understanding of the high-power laser processes so that high solar cell performance can be achieved at reduced manufacturing cost. Research results will allow the solar industry to easily adapt laser-based processes for the manufacturing of high performance, low-cost solar cells. The growth of alternative energy sources will have an important impact on the society to meet its energy needs and will lower the nation?s dependence on foreign oil.

A combined experimental and computational investigation will be carried out on the laser-induced defects generation during silicon solar cell fabrication processes and ways to mitigate their effect through control of laser process parameters. Technical objectives of the research include: experimental examination of laser-induced material modification and atomistic modeling of laser interactions with silicon substrate; control of defects through optimization of laser processing parameters such as laser beam profile, laser power, and laser repetition rate; and understanding the effect of post processing steps on defect recovery as well as on solar cell device performance. Education will be an integral part of the effort by involvement of undergraduate and graduate students. Research results will be included in the lectures on solar energy and photonics. Also, the Principal Investigators plan to develop an educational module in photovoltaics and laser applications area, which will target seniors and first-year graduate students. The goal will be to grow this activity further by involvement of teachers and students, as well as display of materials at Science Museum of Virginia and Charlottesville local library.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Laser Processing Method to Reduce Solar Cell Manufacturing Cost and Enhancement of Performance

This research project is aimed at providing new ideas and establishing optimum conditions for the application of laser processing to reduce solar cell manufacturing costs and enhance the performance of photovoltaic devices. Silicon-based solar cells continue to dominate the solar-energy market, accounting for over 90% of all solar cell products in the world. The decrease in the manufacturing cost of silicon solar cells is extremely important for solar-energy technology to be a viable alternative energy source. High-power lasers provide an attractive method to lower the cost of solar cell manufacturing. However, further research is required in order to make high-power laser-based processing viable for solar cell manufacturing. This research is focused on scientific understanding of complex structural and phase transformations induced by the high-power lasers so that high solar cell performance can be achieved at reduced manufacturing cost. 

            A combined experimental and computational investigation was carried out on the laser-induced defects generation during silicon solar cell fabrication processes and ways to mitigate their effect through control of laser process parameters. For a wider acceptance of laser-based silicon solar cell fabrication, three research goals were met: (1) an improved fundamental understanding of defect generation mechanisms was achieved and damage-limiting laser-processing conditions were identified; (2) the mitigation of laser-induced defects using post-laser surface annealing was demonstrated; and (3) the defect-controlled and annealing processes in laser-based silicon solar cell devices were established. A combination of atomistic and continuum-level computational methods was used to reveal the mechanisms responsible for the laser-induced modification of surface morphology and microstructure in Si under a wide range of laser irradiation conditions.

            The processes of laser-induced melting, resolidification, and generation of crystal defects in a-Si wafer are investigated with a continuum-level model parametrized based on the results of atomistic simulations. The effects of laser parameters on the concentration of point defects in the transiently melted region and the mitigation of point defects through low power laser annealing were examined and related to experimental observations. The irradiation regimes corresponding to different surface microstructures, with amorphous regions formed either at the center or at the periphery of the laser spot, are established for a broad range of laser fluence, pulse duration, and spot size.

            Moreover, the efficiency of the post-laser annealing technique in removing the laser-processing-induced defects was investigated, and approaches for integration of this technique into the laser-based solar cell fabrication process were suggested. The minimization of laser-induced defects in laser-based solar cell fabrication, including laser transfer doping, laser-transferred metal contacts, and laser ablation of metals for contact isolation was demonstrated. Through incorporation of these laser-based processes with laser annealing, we fabricated all-laser-based interdigitated back contact silicon solar cells and demonstrated that post-laser annealing could considerably improve conversion efficiency.

            Overall, a fundamental understanding of laser-induced defects in Si has been provided through experimental and computational studies, and a novel and viable concept of high-power laser processing with low-power laser annealing has been demonstrated for high-efficiency and low-cost silicon solar cell fabrication. It is concluded that laser-induced defects can be minimized by tailoring laser-processing conditions. The research results have been reported in several papers published in peer-reviewed scientific journals and book chapters.

            For a broader impact, education was an integral part of the effort by the involvement of two graduate students and several undergraduate students. Two graduate students received their Ph.D. degrees in the research area of laser processing of silicon. The thesis titles were “Laser-Induced Defects in Silicon Solar Cells and Laser Annealing” and “Atomistic and Continuum Modeling of Laser-Induced Phase Transformations, Generation of Crystal Defects, and Modification of Surface Morphology in Silicon and Metal Targets.” To enhance the interest of students in science and engineering and public knowledge the research results were displayed at the local Charlottesville library, and a guest lecture was presented at the Charlottesville High School Science Club.
